table:
Set display mode

0 = 40x25 monochrome text
1 = 40x25 color text
2 = 80x25 monochrome text
3 = 80x25 color text
4 = 320x200 color graphics
5 = 320x200 monochrome graphics
6 = 640x200 monochrome graphics
7 = wrap at end of line
Clear line from cursor to end of line

Reset display mode

0 = 40x25 monochrome text
1 = 40x25 color text
2 = 80x25 monochrome text
3 = 80x25 color text
4 = 320x200 color graphics
5 = 320x200 monochrome graphics
6 = 640x200 monochrome graphics
7 = disable wrap at end of line

notes: PC programmer's sourcebook (1988) incorrectly lists 7 as wrap at end of line
Any number of parameters is valid, including none

If no number given, acts as if zero.
Each number changes an attribute that will be used to print text after the escape.
0 clears all attributes to default.
See table "MS-DOS Prompt ANSI Display Attribute Strings" for more information.

1: key to remap
2: key to remap to
Reassigns first key (1) to second key (2), or remap key (1)
Moves cursor up by the number of rows indicated. If not specified, 1 is assumed
Moves cursor down by the number of rows indicated. If not specified, 1 is assumed
Moves cursor right by the number of columns indicated. If not specified, 1 is assumed
Moves cusror left by the number of columns indicated. If not specified, 1 is assumed
Moves cursor to Home position (row 1, column 1)
Moves cursor to row (first #) and column (second #) position
Erasure. MS-DOS only supports 2J to clear the screen according to PC Programmer's Sourcebook (1988)
Erase from cursor to end of line, including cursor position
Report cursor position through standard input
Console driver outputs cursor position report sequence
